newsitem.title: CHINA: Analysts favour Shanghai Worldbest Co shares.
newsitem.headline: Analysts favour Shanghai Worldbest Co shares.

text.p: Shanghai Worldbest Co stocks are worth holding after the firm's 1996 net profit soared 135.69 percent, and it faces a promising year ahead, analysts said on Tuesday.

"Worldbest's 1996 results are satisfactory," said a local analyst. "The company's production technology is advanced, which brings them high profit margins, so we recommend a holding of the company's stock."

Worldbest, a textile company, issued annual results on Monday showing net profit surged to 79.087 million yuan ($9.5 million) in 1996, up from 1995's 33.555 million yuan based on international accounting standards.
Based on domestic accounting standards, 1996 net was 80.24 million yuan. The company had targeted a net profit of around 80 million yuan for 1996.
"The result is ahead of our expectations," said an analyst with a foreign brokerage based in Shanghai. "It is likely to show decent growth in 1997."
Worldbest said on Tuesday that good management, including proper acquisitions of other firms' shares, helped boost its post-tax 1996 profits by 135.69 percent.

"In 1996, the company tried its best to improve management, develop new products and activate sales, which guaranteed the fulfillment of its profit target," the company said in its 1996 annual report published on Tuesday.
The company listed foreign currency B shares on the Shanghai Stock Exchange on July 26, 1996.

After the listing, the firm bought controlling stakes in Changzhou Huachang Dying Industrial Co, a Sino-South Korean joint venture, and Changzhou Worldbest Radici Engineering Plastic Co, a Sino-Italian joint venture, the report said.
These purchases had strengthened its capacity to produce chemical fibres, it said.
An analyst with the company's main underwriter, Haitong Securities Co, said the results were in line with expectations.
"The company's results and dividends are both okay, and meet the market's expectation," the analyst said. "The company has only been listed for five months so the dividend is reasonable."
The company's board of directors proposes a pre-tax cash dividend of 0.105 yuan per share for B share holders, the company annual report said.

Analysts said Worldbest was likely to continue its upward trend in 1997. Its joint ventures should soon start moving into profit and newly-imported assembly-lines and equipment will produce more polyester and boost profit margins, they said.

"The company's net profit is expected to rise to around 100 million yuan once its joint ventures and new assembly-lines become fully operational," said an analyst with one of the largest China brokerage houses.
"Its main products -- differential polyester filaments -- will see profit margins of 25 to 30 percent," he said.
The company's annual report said assembly lines imported from Japan will boost annual polyester production capacity by 4,000 tonnes once they go into operation in April.
Changzhou Huachang Dying Industrial Co, 75-percent controlled by Worldbest, has annual silk dying capacity of 200 million metres (218 million yards), the annual report said.
Changzhou Worldbest Radici Engineering Plastic will boast annual production capacity of 60,000 tonnes of plastics by the end of 1997, it said.
Worldbest's B shares ended at $0.514 on Tuesday, up $0.006 or 1.18 percent from Monday's close, as the second heaviest trade of 1.29 million shares.
